Recently in Nature Neuroscience, Gaillard et al., 2007Gaillard A. Prestoz L. Dumartin B. Cantereau A. Morel F. Roger M. Jaber M. Nat. Neurosci. 2007; (in press. Published online September 2, 2007)https://doi.org/10.1038/nn1970Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar study axonal projections from embryonic cortical explants grafted into acutely damaged adult motor cortex. After attempting to rule out fusion of donor tissue with pre-existing host circuitry, the authors report robust long-distance donor axonal projections and synaptic integration into target regions appropriate for the motor system. Recently in Nature Neuroscience, Gaillard et al., 2007Gaillard A. Prestoz L. Dumartin B. Cantereau A. Morel F. Roger M. Jaber M. Nat. Neurosci. 2007; (in press. Published online September 2, 2007)https://doi.org/10.1038/nn1970Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar study axonal projections from embryonic cortical explants grafted into acutely damaged adult motor cortex. After attempting to rule out fusion of donor tissue with pre-existing host circuitry, the authors report robust long-distance donor axonal projections and synaptic integration into target regions appropriate for the motor system. It is an intricate journey from the developing neuroectoderm—populated by uncommitted multipotent neural stem cells (NSCs)—to the highly specific synaptic contacts that, for example, precisely move one's finger. As development of the central nervous system (CNS) proceeds, the neural tube generates billions of neurons that are interconnected through axons, establishing trillions of synapses. In this highly complex and tightly controlled network, one neuron can establish >10,000 synapses with another neuron. It seems daunting to think that a cellular suspension of exogenous NSCs transplanted into a damaged cortex of an adult brain should be able to recapitulate such precision and complexity. And, in general, it has been quite difficult to achieve. Even under conditions where functional recovery has been observed after the implantation of stem cells into the lesioned CNS, the underlying mechanism has often turned out to be not primarily neuronal replacement but rather the stem cell-mediated protection of pre-existing neuronal networks. This phenomenon, called the “chaperone effect” (Ourednik et al., 2002Ourednik J. Ourednik V. Lynch W.P. Schachner M. Snyder E.Y. Nat. Biotechnol. 2002; 20: 1103-1110Crossref PubMed Scopus (430) Google Scholar), has actually come to be viewed as “low-hanging fruit” in the stem cell field for many types of abnormalities in many organ systems (e.g., heart, muscle, pancreas, bone, in addition to CNS). Nevertheless, neuronal replacement remains the Holy Grail of regenerative medicine, although we have all come to recognize how challenging that is. A recent paper by Gaillard et al., 2007Gaillard A. Prestoz L. Dumartin B. Cantereau A. Morel F. Roger M. Jaber M. Nat. Neurosci. 2007; (in press. Published online September 2, 2007)https://doi.org/10.1038/nn1970Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar offers some hope that we may need not abandon that lofty goal and provides some insights into what we might need to achieve as preconditions for replacement of neural circuitry. Endogenous and grafted neural stem/progenitor cells do have the ability to generate projection neurons in the neocortex (Snyder et al., 1997Snyder E.Y. Yoon C. Flax J.D. Macklis J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 1997; 94: 11663-11668Crossref PubMed Scopus (397) Google Scholar, Park et al., 2002Park K.I. Teng Y.D. Snyder E.Y. Nat. Biotechnol. 2002; 20: 1111-1117Crossref PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar, Chen et al., 2004Chen J. Magavi S.S. Macklis J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2004; 101: 16357-16362Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar, Molyneaux et al., 2007Molyneaux B.J. Arlotta P. Menezes J.R. Macklis J.D. Nat. Rev. Neurosci. 2007; 8: 427-437Crossref PubMed Scopus (1050) Google Scholar)—however, with low efficiency. Prevailing thought holds that this low incidence of neuronal replacement is rooted in the realization that NSCs in a cellular suspension, removed from their instructive and contextual cues, do not efficiently acquire an identity with sufficient refinement to become neurons that “know” to restore discrete and specialized connections. Gaillard et al., 2007Gaillard A. Prestoz L. Dumartin B. Cantereau A. Morel F. Roger M. Jaber M. Nat. Neurosci. 2007; (in press. Published online September 2, 2007)https://doi.org/10.1038/nn1970Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar, however, demonstrate that, if we retain (or, presumably, provide) those contextual cues, as one does with a fetal cortical organotypic explant, one can achieve fairly robust neuronal connectivity in a complex system. The authors used a straightforward approach. They aspirated the motor cortex of 4- to 6-month-old male mice and immediately grafted into the lesion cavity embryonic motor cortex explanted from green fluorescent protein (GFP)-expressing female mice. Animals analyzed at 2 months postgrafting showed exuberant long-distance axonal projections and anatomical restoration. Large numbers of GFP-expressing axons were found in the appropriate cortical and subcortical target areas of the motor pathway bilaterally. (Functional recovery was, unfortunately, not studied.) To verify de novo extension of myelinated efferents and synaptogenesis, and to rule out fusion with host cells as an alternative mechanism, a series of experiments were performed, including axonal tracing, immunogold electron microscopy, immunostaining for developmental markers at early postgrafting stages, and FISH to rule out the colocalization of GFP (a donor cell marker) in a Y chromosome-bearing cell (indicative of host derivation). Importantly, embryonic visual cortex grafted into the same lesion cavity did not result in motor pathway-specific projections. Instead, those grafts elaborated axons to brain regions in the visual pathway, suggesting that there are limits to plasticity, not dissimilar from the older fetal transplant literature that showed that heterotopic cortical transplants prior to a critical stage adopted features of the host region but retained the phenotype of their origin if grafted after that critical point (McConnell, 1988McConnell S.K. J. Neurosci. 1988; 8: 945-974PubMed Google Scholar). Hence, timing and priming are key. Why did the authors observe such axonal projections in a surprisingly short period of time? This result, if replicated and validated, would likely be attributable not only to factors in the graft—cells obtained at the proper developmental stage from the proper region maintaining their proper contextual cues—but also to factors in the host. Transplants were performed immediately after lesioning. Although the authors did not compare results from this procedure with those from delayed grafting, such an acute intervention presumably capitalized on a favorable recipient milieu: minimal postinjury inflammation, excitotoxicity, and scarring; the transient recapitulation of embryonic neurogenic cues (Snyder et al., 1997Snyder E.Y. Yoon C. Flax J.D. Macklis J.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 1997; 94: 11663-11668Crossref PubMed Scopus (397) Google Scholar); and abundant neurotrophic support and residual guidance cues. New axons may readily have taken over recently vacated synaptic fields of the lesioned motor pathway that otherwise, if time had been allowed to pass, might have received aberrant axonal sprouting from neighboring systems (Hofstetter et al., 2005Hofstetter C.P. Holmstrom N.A. Lilja J.A. Schweinhardt P. Hao J. Spenger C. Wiesenfeld-Hallin Z. Kurpad S.N. Frisen J. Olson L. Nat. Neurosci. 2005; 8: 346-353Crossref PubMed Scopus (502) Google Scholar). Hence, timing of transplantation is probably a critical factor for motor pathway restoration. When therapy is delayed, formation of large cysts often complicates some brain injuries. Seeding cells upon implantable biodegradable scaffolds might address this problem by recreating the three-dimensional context Park et al., 2002Park K.I. Teng Y.D. Snyder E.Y. Nat. Biotechnol. 2002; 20: 1111-1117Crossref PubMed Scopus (476) Google Scholar found so vital (Gaillard et al., 2007Gaillard A. Prestoz L. Dumartin B. Cantereau A. Morel F. Roger M. Jaber M. Nat. Neurosci. 2007; (in press. Published online September 2, 2007)https://doi.org/10.1038/nn1970Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). The limitation, of course, would be the impediments to reconstruction raised by the host over time, ranging from scarring to developmentally timed obstacles. During development, axons find their way correctly by responding to a precisely regulated balance between chemoattractive and chemorepellent microenvironmental cues. In adulthood, most brain regions are nonpermissive of axonal plasticity and sprouting. Once synaptic vacancies are occupied by ingrowing axons, these areas are often no longer accessible. Inhibitory molecules (e.g., Nogo-A, MAG) on adult CNS myelin suppress axonal growth (Buchli and Schwab, 2005Buchli A.D. Schwab M.E. Ann. Med. 2005; 37: 556-567Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar). Given these obstacles, why did so many axons, as reported by Gaillard et al., 2007Gaillard A. Prestoz L. Dumartin B. Cantereau A. Morel F. Roger M. Jaber M. Nat. Neurosci. 2007; (in press. Published online September 2, 2007)https://doi.org/10.1038/nn1970Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar, grow in a presumably nonpermissive environment? The authors do not address this point. It might be that embryonic cortical motor neurons are special in some way in being less susceptible to inhibition; however, visual cortical grafts also grew—albeit to different targets. Systems may differ in their receptiveness for repair. For example, in the nigrostriatal system, projections to the striatum from fetal dopamine neurons grafted into the young adult rat midbrain are poor (Bentlage et al., 1999Bentlage C. Nikkhah G. Cunningham M.G. Bjorklund A. Exp. Neurol. 1999; 159: 177-190Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). The lesson is not to overgeneralize from one system or cell type to another. We have learned over the past two decades that there is greater plasticity in the normal and injured adult CNS than previously anticipated, regulated at multiple levels: molecular, cellular, synaptic, and behavioral. From studies like that of Gaillard et al., 2007Gaillard A. Prestoz L. Dumartin B. Cantereau A. Morel F. Roger M. Jaber M. Nat. Neurosci. 2007; (in press. Published online September 2, 2007)https://doi.org/10.1038/nn1970Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar, we learn that, if we could expose stem cells to the proper array of signals, then such regeneration might come under our control. Discerning those signals, it seems, is worth the effort. We wish to dedicate this article to our colleague Peter S. Eriksson (1959–2007) in recognition of his seminal contributions to adult neurogenesis and human neuroanatomy. I.S. is a Merck Foundation Scholar, supported also by the American Parkinson's Disease Association.

Australia's strong historical foundation in stem cell science was boosted in 2002 by the formation of a virtual government-supported institute now called the Australian Stem Cell Centre. However, the inevitable "brain drain" and government and community expectations of quick commercial gains and rapid cures necessitate careful reconsideration of the identity and future of stem cell science in Australia.

In recent years, stem cell research has taken on a global character, fueling funding initiatives and political discussions in countries around the world. Stem cell research organizations must necessarily follow suit if they are to address the needs and concerns of a truly international membership. The International Society for Stem Cell Research (ISSCR), a nonprofit organization formed in 2002, serves its diverse membership as well as other stakeholders by providing a global forum for learning about and discussing the latest issues, challenges, and advances in stem cell biology and related fields.

Although human and mouse embryonic stem cells share many characteristics, their behaviors are not identical. Two recent papers describe the derivation of stem cell lines from mouse epiblast that may provide an explanation for the unique character of human embryonic stem cells. Although human and mouse embryonic stem cells share many characteristics, their behaviors are not identical. Two recent papers describe the derivation of stem cell lines from mouse epiblast that may provide an explanation for the unique character of human embryonic stem cells. The capacity of embryonic stem cells to self-renew indefinitely while maintaining their potential to differentiate into any cell in the embryo has been a valuable tool for mouse geneticists for decades (Bradley et al., 1984Bradley A. Evans M. Kaufman M.H. Robertson E. Nature. 1984; 309: 255-256Crossref PubMed Scopus (1057) Google Scholar). The subsequent derivation of these cells in primates (Thomson et al., 1998Thomson J.A. Itskovitz-Eldor J. Shapiro S.S. Waknitz M.A. Swiergiel J.J. Marshall V.S. Jones J.M. Science. 1998; 282 (Erratum: (1998). Science 282, 1827): 1145-1147Crossref PubMed Scopus (11509) Google Scholar) has revolutionized the way we think about both transplantation medicine and drug discovery. However, despite the time that has passed since embryonic stem cells were first derived, many questions concerning the nature of these cells persist. What counterpart, if any, do these cells have within the embryo in vivo? What is the explanation for the differences in behavior between mouse embryonic stem cells and their human counterparts? Why has it been so difficult to derive embryonic stem cell lines from other species of animals, despite the clear benefits that the application of such cells would bring? Two recent papers published in the journal Nature, one from the McKay lab (Tesar et al., 2007Tesar P.J. Chenoweth J.G. Brook F.A. Davies T.J. Evans E.P. Mack D.L. Gardner R.L. McKay R.D. Nature. 2007; 448: 196-199Crossref PubMed Scopus (1569) Google Scholar) and the other by Vallier and colleagues (Brons et al., 2007Brons I.G. Smithers L.E. Trotter M.W. Rugg-Gunn P. Sun B. Chuva de Sousa Lopes S.M. Howlett S.K. Clarkson A. Ahrlund-Richter L. Pedersen R.A. Vallier L. Nature. 2007; 448: 191-195Crossref PubMed Scopus (1426) Google Scholar), shed light on these interesting questions. In both reports, the authors describe the derivation of self-renewing, pluripotent populations of cells from the epiblast of postimplantation mouse embryos, a later developmental stage than the blastocysts used previously. These cells are similar to other mouse embryonic stem cell lines in that they can form embryoid bodies in culture and teratomas in nude mice, and within these masses, differentiated cells from each of the three embryonic germ layers are generated. However, these “epiblast stem cells,” as the authors dubbed them, seem to be distinct from mouse embryonic stem cells derived from blastocyst stage embryos in several ways. Of particular note, many of the altered traits observed in epiblast stem cells are consistent with the salient characteristics of human embryonic stem cells. These new pluripotent mouse cell lines appear to have gene expression patterns distinct from blastocyst-derived embryonic stem cells; require Activin, rather than LIF signaling for self-renewal; and grow in tight epithelial structures reminiscent of human embryonic stem cells. Because of their derivation from postimplantation epiblast, and as Activin/Nodal signaling is important for maintenance of both the mouse epiblast in vivo (Camus et al., 2006Camus A. Perea-Gomez A. Moreau A. Collignon J. Dev. Biol. 2006; 295: 743-755Crossref PubMed Scopus (152) Google Scholar) and human embryonic stem cells in vitro (James et al., 2005James D. Levine A.J. Besser D. Hemmati-Brivanlou A. Development. 2005; 132: 1273-1282Crossref PubMed Scopus (701) Google Scholar), it is tempting to speculate, as the authors do, that the derivation of these new mouse stem cell lines indicates that human embryonic stem cells might represent a short circuiting of human epiblast development and the capture of an in vitro counterpart to these cells. Consistent with this notion, when the authors transplanted these cells into preimplantation blastocysts they possessed very limited or no ability to contribute to the resulting embryo. Thus far, most mammalian species have been refractory to the derivation of embryonic stem cell lines of the type cultured from mouse blastocysts. In their study, Brons and colleagues also demonstrate that these epiblast stem cells can be derived from rat embryos, a model organism from which there have been numerous but unsuccessful attempts to derive embryonic stem cell lines. The generation of these similar cell lines from mouse, human, and rat suggests that encouraging the self-renewal of epiblast cells may be a more applicable Rosetta stone for translating the derivation of pluripotent stem cells into other species. However, if these cells cannot be forced to contribute in a meaningful way to chimeric offspring, as the authors found for their mouse epiblast stem cells, the utility of the orthologous cells will be greatly limited. Although these studies are significant, they leave several questions unaddressed and ripe for further investigation. In their studies, Tesar and Brons were only able to isolate these cells from postimplantation embryos and not blastocyst stage embryos. This would be consistent with an epiblast origin and nature for these cells. However, why then can primate and human embryonic stem cells be derived from blastocyst stage embryos and why do primate, but not murine, blastocyst-derived cells have similar characteristics to their postimplantation-derived mouse counterparts? Is it that cells within the inner cell mass of human blastocysts are beginning to adopt epiblast characteristics and it is these cells that become human embryonic stem cells? If so, would prolonging the in vitro culture of human blastocysts prior to derivation increase the efficiency of human embryonic stem cell derivation? Furthermore, would these later cell lines have the same characteristics found in existing human embryonic stem cell lines? A perhaps more perplexing question is, if these new mouse stem cell lines and human embryonic stem cells represent a self-renewing population of definitive embryonic epiblast cells, why then do both of these populations retain the capacity to differentiate into extraembryonic trophectoderm and primitive endoderm? Lineage tracing experiments in mice would suggest that the epiblast has extremely limited capacity, if any, to differentiate into these cells types (Gardner and Rossant, 1979Gardner R.L. Rossant J. J. Embryol. Exp. Morphol. 1979; 52: 141-152PubMed Google Scholar, Lawson et al., 1991Lawson K.A. Meneses J.J. Pedersen R.A. Development. 1991; 113: 891-911PubMed Google Scholar), while the cultured epiblast stem cell lines seem to adopt these cell fates readily. Could it be that without the constraints of their in vivo environment this wider developmental potential for epiblast cells is revealed? Does prolonged in vitro culture somehow lead to an expansion of developmental potential, or is there some other explanation for the remarkable potential of both these epiblast-derived mouse cells and human embryonic stem cells? Regardless of the answers to these questions, the work of Brons and Tesar and their colleagues has provided exciting new information concerning the nature and origins of both mouse and human embryonic stem cells, suggesting a potential explanation for their distinct biology.

A recent publication in Nature by North et al. (2007) has implicated the eicosanoid prostaglandin E2 in enhancement of hematopoietic stem cell function in zebrafish and in mice. This work may have practical therapeutic value, but much remains to be determined before this possibility is realized.
